title: Extended FAB
description: Extended FABs help people take primary actions. They're wider than FABs to accommodate a text label and larger target area.

contentChunks.htmlValue: Extended FABs are the most visually prominent button.

contentChunks.footer:
1. Extended FAB with both icon and label text
2. Extended FAB without icon
contentChunks.altText: 2 examples of extended FABs

contentChunks.htmlValue: Resources

TypeLinkStatus
DesignDesign kit (Figma)Available
M2 guideline – extended FABAvailable
ImplementationMDC-AndroidAvailable
Jetpack ComposeAvailable
FlutterAvailable
WebPlanned
Takeaways

• Extended FABs are the most prominent type of button
  • Use an extended FAB to provide persistent access to a primary action above long-scrolling surface content
  • Because it has room for both a text label and an icon, the extended FAB can be more effective where an icon alone might be too ambiguous
What's new

• Color: New color mappings and compatibility with dynamic color
  • Layout: Extended FAB is the same height as the FAB
  • Shape: Boxier style with smaller corner radius

contentChunks.footer: Extended FABs have the same height as FABs.
contentChunks.altText: 1 FAB on the left, 1 extended FAB on the right both the same height

contentChunks.footer: M2: Extended FABs are pill-shaped and have a different height and elevation.
contentChunks.altText: Pill-shaped M2 extended FAB

contentChunks.footer: M3: Extended FABs share the same height as FABs, have a boxier shape, and a simpler elevation model.
contentChunks.altText: Boxier M3 Extended FAB

Color

Color values are implemented through design tokens. For design, this means working with color values that correspond with tokens. For implementation, a color value will be a token that references a value. Learn more about design tokens.

Additional color mappings

Extended FABs can use other combinations of container and icon colors. The color mappings below provide the same legibility and functionality as the default, so the color mapping you use depends on style alone.

* When using a non-default color mapping for extended FABs, make sure the state layer color is the same as the icon color. For example, the state layer color for the Surface mapping should be md.sys.color.primary.

contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB in bright green color, set on lighter background

contentChunks.htmlValue: Usage
Use an extended FAB on screens with long, scrolling views that require persistent access to an action, such as a check-out screen. Do not use an extended FAB in a view that cannot scroll.

contentChunks.footer: Extended FAB displaying a main action.
contentChunks.altText: Example of extended FAB used for Checkout

contentChunks.footer: Use an extended FAB to provide persistent access to a primary action above long-scrolling surface content.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB situated on lower right screen, above bottom navigation

contentChunks.footer: Use an extended FAB to provide persistent access to the screen's primary action.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB placed on lower right screen, above bottom navigation

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use an extended FAB in a non-scrolling view.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB

contentChunks.footer: If a primary action is needed in a non-scrolling view, use a button instead.
contentChunks.altText: Filled button

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Additional emphasis

The extended FAB can also provide more emphasis and clarity to a product’s primary action. Because it has room for both a text label and an icon, the extended FAB can be effective where an icon alone might be too ambiguous. However, the relationship between an extended FAB's icon and label should still be clear.

contentChunks.footer: An extended FAB can be effective where an icon alone might be too vague.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB above bottom navigation

contentChunks.htmlValue: Like the default FAB, only one extended FAB should be used per screen. Multiple instances overwhelm the layout and disrupt its prominence as the most visible component. If an additional high-level action needs to be shown, pair the extended FAB with a small FAB.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use multiple extended FABs in one screen as it disrupts visual hierarchy
contentChunks.altText: 2 extended FABs set on 1 screen

contentChunks.footer: If multiple affordances are necessary, use a small FAB for one of the actions.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB and small FABon screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: The extended FAB should not be used as an option in a set of actions. In this case, a regular button is more appropriate.

contentChunks.footer: Don’t use the extended FAB to convey an option in a set of actions.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB at bottom of screen

contentChunks.footer: Use a regular button (styled with emphasis in mind) to present optionality.
contentChunks.altText: Filled button set at lower right screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: Anatomy

contentChunks.footer:
1. Container
2. Label text
3. Icon
contentChunks.altText: Diagram of 3 extended FAB elements

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Container

Extended FAB containers have a rounded rectangle shape.

The width of an extended FAB’s container can be fixed or fluid.

A fixed-width container is defined by the cumulative width of the icon, text label, and padding.

contentChunks.footer: This extended FAB's fixed width is defined by the cumulative width of the icon, text label, and container padding.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB on center, lower screen

contentChunks.htmlValue: A fluid-width container is defined by its relationship to the dimensions of the screen, such as screen width or layout grid.

contentChunks.footer: This extended FAB's container width is defined by the layout grid columns.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB within layout grid

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon

The icon of an extended FAB should intuitively represent its action.

contentChunks.footer: Icons should be placed to the left of text labels for left-to-right (LTR) languages.

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Icon

The icon of an extended FAB should intuitively represent its action.

contentChunks.footer: cons should be placed to the left of text labels for left-to-right (LTR) languages.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB on lower right screen

contentChunks.footer: Icons should be placed to the right for right-to-left (RTL) languages.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB on lower left screen

contentChunks.footer: Unlike standard FABs, extended FABs don't require an icon.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB with text label “Save draft” in lower right screen

contentChunks.footer: An extended FAB can't have an icon without a text label.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB with icon only

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Label text

The label of an extended FAB should describe its action.

contentChunks.footer: Only truncate text if shorter text isn't an option.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB with truncated text

contentChunks.footer: Avoid wrapping text.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB featuring wrapped text

contentChunks.htmlValue: Placement

contentChunks.footer: Don’t place the extended FAB in the upper half of a mobile screen, as it disrupts the reading of the UI.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB set in upper left screen

contentChunks.footer: Don’t place extended FABs on cards or inside other containers.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB within a dialog

contentChunks.footer: Don’t overlay the FAB on app bars as it disrupts the elevation story.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB on a bottom app bar

contentChunks.footer: Place the extended FAB above the rest of the UI, off of elements like app bars.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB placed above navigation bar

contentChunks.htmlValue: Responsive layout
If space becomes limited, the extended FAB can transform into a standard FAB. For example, if an app window is resized below 840dp, or a navigation drawer opens up.

contentChunks.footer: When space is limited, an extended FAB transforms into a standard FAB
contentChunks.altText: Example of extended FAB morphing into standard FAB

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Mobile

On a mobile device, the extended FAB should be placed at the bottom of the screen, either center-aligned or aligned to the ending edge of the screen (right-aligned for RTL languages and left-aligned for LTR languages).

contentChunks.footer: On a mobile device, the extended FAB can be center-aligned.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB centered on bottom screen

contentChunks.footer: On a mobile device, the extended FAB can be right-aligned for RTL languages or left-aligned for LTR languages.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB aligned right

contentChunks.footer: Avoid using an extended FAB above a bottom app bar, as the combination takes up a lot of screen space. If they are paired, the extended FAB should collapse on scroll.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB above bottom app bar

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Tablet and desktop

For UIs larger than 840dp, such as tablets, the extended FAB should appear at the bottom right of the screen, or within the navigation drawer.

contentChunks.footer: The extended FAB placed at the bottom right
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB at bottom right of screen

contentChunks.footer: The extended FAB within a navigation drawer
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB in navigation drawer

contentChunks.htmlValue: Behavior

Appearing

The extended FAB surface expands when appearing on screen using an enter and exit transition pattern.

contentChunks.footer: An extended FAB can expand and adapt to any shape.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB adapting to various shapes

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Expanding

The extended FAB can expand and adapt to any shape using a container transform transition pattern. This includes a surface that is part of the app structure, or a surface that spans the entire screen.

contentChunks.footer: An extended FAB can expand and adapt to any shape.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB adapting to various shapes

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Transforming

The extended FAB collapses on scroll and expands on reaching the bottom of the view.

contentChunks.footer: An extended FAB collapses and expands while scrolling until reaching the bottom of the view.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB transforming to fit view

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Scrolling

The extended FAB collapses on scroll and expands on user’s scrolling up.

contentChunks.footer: The extended FAB collapses and expands when scrolled up.
contentChunks.altText: Extended FAB transformed while scrolling

contentChunks.htmlValue:
When the FAB switches to an extended FAB, the following transitions occur:

  • The FAB shape changes to a pill shape from the circular shape;
  • FAB icon moves to the left;
  • FAB text label fades in.

contentChunks.footer: FAB switches to an extended FAB
contentChunks.altText: FAB changing into extended FAB

contentChunks.htmlValue:
Accessibility guidelines coming soon

In progress: complete guidance for accessible interaction, keyboard navigation, labeling, and more. Learn more about accessibility.
